Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer deny procedural fairness by not informing the applicant of concerns and not conducting an interview?
Evidence_Assessment: Employment letter found insufficient as it mirrored NOC descriptions without additional details
Decision_Outcome: Permanent residency application denied due to insufficient proof of work experience
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must provide evidence of one year of full-time employment in a skilled occupation
Credibility_Factor: Document veracity questioned; implied fraud without clarification opportunity
Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires informing applicants if document vericity is questioned
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Procedural_Issue: Lack of notice and opportunity to respond to credibility concerns
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; decision set aside due to procedural unfairness
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Breach found: applicant not informed of concerns or given chance to clarify
Key_Evidence_Considered: Employment letter lacking specific details, resembling NOC description
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Applicant_Challenge: Denial of permanent residency based on insufficient work experience proof
Court_Result: Officer's decision set aside; matter referred to a different officer for reassessment
Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities (implied in administrative immigration cases)
Outcome: Decision set aside, new assessment ordered
Remedy_Sought: Procedural fairness and re-evaluation by a different officer
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of IRPA
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Authority: Immigration Division / Visa Office / Federal Court
Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, IRPA s. 72(1)
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient proof of required work experience
Outcome_of_Review: In favor of applicant on procedural grounds
